column4: Okay, Ubuntu has to do some SERIOUS work on Bluetooth... it is dreadful.
Honestly I felt the 9.10 release was a step back in many ways -- not just bluetooth
I have been trying for over  amonth now to get bluetooth working... and the Gnome stuff sucks.
It neither detects my cellphone via the bluetooth dongle, and my phone detects the computer but cannot connect.
have you looked into a Bluetooth manager like Blueman -- not sure if this would help solve the issue or not
I installed blueman... same problem.  Except that blueman cannot be found anywhere.
hm, sorry to heard that... let me see if there is anything I may be able to find and suggest
I wish you would.
Uninstalling all 'blue' entries in Synaptic and reinstalling them made no difference either.
are you using wireless or hardwired internet connection?
You mean to chat here?  Or when I use bluetooth?
on the machine that you use bluetooth with [when your using it]
hm, ok. I read a few places that individuals were needing specific wireless card drivers [when connecting via wi-fi] for the bluetooth to also work
This is a bluetooth problem.  It worked.  Now it does not.  Bluetooth-applet no longer detects cellphone.
I am trying that now'
that's one that you should be able to run after disabling bluetooth
have you also tried uninstalling bluetooth through the synaptic package manager?
Yep.

Configuration information is located in the /etc/bluetooth directory, along with the /etc/pcmcia directory for notebooks. The HCI information is saved in /etc/bluetooth/hcid.conf, and RFCOMM configuration information is in /etc/bluetooth/rfcomm.conf. The Bluetooth service script, /etc/rc.d/init.d/bluetooth, is used to start and stop Bluetooth services. This script will start up the Bluetooth daemon for HCI devices, hcid, and run any dete
no problem, trying to see what I can do http://computingtech.blogspot.com/2009/01/using-bluetooth-in-ubuntu.html
thanks for trying buddy.
sorry couldn't be of more help!
